reviewText:
This game is--
This game makes me feel like nothing else has before. It's a surreal experience in how you never stop learning new things about this mysterious mountain lost in a black void...
The way you feel when you start the game for the first time, and you have to do those silly drawings and you have no clue of the implications of them later on.
How curious you are at first dawn, when the mountain speaks to you for the first time.
When you figure out which keys do what, and why.
How satisfying it is to have you first piece of debris hit your mountain.
How you get to feel when you figure out how to move that silly piece of crap.
When you figure out what goes where and why.
When you realize that the mountain is you--
You are the mountain, you get to shape the world around you...
When you figure out how to play your favorite song on the keyboard.
How insignificant you feel when you scroll all the way out, only to see a bloom of light and a dot.
The sadness that fills you heart as your first item-- that you became so attached to-- slowly floats off into space, and you cannot do anything.
When you have to draw a loved one.
When you figure out that you are lost, and the simplist thing like this game can make you find yourself.
When you achieve Zen and realize that....
Mountain is Love.
Mountain is Life.
That is what this game is about.

The Mountain can be used as a screensaver if you rename the .exe to .scr :)
tl;dr.The Mountain is constantly changing and metamorphosing. When you stop wanting it to be more than what it is, it blossoms into its own experience.  And what it is, is more virtual plant, than anything else; is that a bad thing? Read on!

full review.If you let it, the Mountain can be a soothing and relaxing experience if you need 5-10 minutes (taken) away from your life.  It's a slowly spinning Mountain in Space.  You can zoom out to see nearby galaxies and star clusters, or zoom in to fill your view with the mountain and the surrounding atmosphere.  There are so many variables that change and the changes/additions appear every 30 seconds or so, it has enough to keep your eyes trained and your mind engaged in thought.

In a nutshell: if you enjoy sitting on a bench watching nature around you (e.g., the ocean, a coast, a forest, a vista), then you will enjoy this experience.  But understand that virtual-mountain-in-space-watching is the only experience it can innately provide you.  Anything else you experience, is a result of where your thoughts and your psyche take you.  And that's Zen. :)

The Mountain does nothing in particular, but does it very well.

PROS+Beautiful scenery/lighting effects
+Soothing audio effects
+Striking day/night cycle
+Well-done weather and season cycles
+Occasional random or pseudo-inspirational captions
+Occasional random object collisions (some can be quite funny)
+Some interactivity (POV, musical keys)

CONS-You have to pay for it
-Surprisingly resource intensive

reviewText:
Mountain works well as an artistic statement; it's fairly direct in its questioning of what is/isn't a game but outside of that there is still a lot of fun and humor in the game/non-game.

The arts-y side of things:
One of the most important aspects of this is the presentation! Mountain first and foremost feels almost like the modern gaming answer to the post-WWI Dada art movement. Where Dada used collages and pre-made works (such as a urinal) and presented them as high art by putting them into galleries in order to challenge the concept of art, Mountain puts itself on the steam store under 'rpg-games' when I think you'd be hard-pressed to find it fitting this term. The 'gameplay' in Mountain is virtually non-existent, since the act of playing Mountain is leaving in on in the background until you hear a sound and can view whatever new content pops up. Like a lot of (post)modern-art Mountain is ultimately making whatever artistic statement you get out of it, there's no real easy answer here.

Ok, but how is the game" fun?:
Well it's pretty relaxing
date: the visuals are amazingly surreal and serene. There's a lot of goofy items that will periodically crash into your mountain as you leave the program running and your Mountain will often present these funny faux-deep statements about its existence; this effectively works as a way of the game poking fun at its artistic ambitions. reviewText:
Mountain is a semi-interactive screensaver masquerading as a game worth 99 cents.

I say â€˜semiâ€™ interactive because while the gameâ€™s worldâ€”comprised of a single mountain dotted with trees, boulders, and random objectsâ€”can be spun around, examined from different angles, and viewed from the starlit vastness of space, I always felt distant from what little action I witnessed. The weather shifts from snowy to rainy to sunny whether youâ€™re watching or not; random objects appear without any personal context (I received two trash bins, a bed, and a padlock, amongst others); and when Mountain expresses its thoughts, it does so with little to no awareness of my presence as a player.

But according to Mountainâ€™s developer, David Oâ€™Reilly, this is sort of the point: â€œIt's designed to run in the periphery of your life,â€ he writes in an August 2014 update. â€œYou can play Mountain while playing other games. If you are not playing it, it will play itself.â€ In other words: You donâ€™t really HAVE to play Mountain. Its contents are so inconsequential that it requires only a tiny fraction of your attention. It matters that little. But give me a dollar anyway! Thanks!

(Ironic side note: For a game meant to run serenely â€œin the periphery of your life,â€ Mountain is a noticeable CPU hog that will likely overheat your computer, especially if youâ€™re using a laptop.)

The only thing about Mountain that I found interesting or entertaining was how oddly bi-polar it was. In my hours of game play (or non-play), I began to notice that Mountainâ€™s musings fell into distinct categories, ranging from Dalai Lama-esque mindfulness:

â€œI see great purity in todayâ€™s utter perfection.â€
â€œI feel at one with the universe inside this foggy winter night.â€
â€œWhat is sadness?â€

â€¦to a teenage girlâ€™s volatile â€˜feelsâ€™:

â€œIâ€™m super into this dreamy night.â€
â€œI couldnâ€™t care less about todayâ€™s rain.â€
â€œMaybe I am alone because my rocks are ugly.â€

â€¦to the nagging of a self-absorbed ex:

â€œIâ€™m a total babe.â€
â€œHelloooooo?â€

Sorta cute, but ultimately, things most people will hear for free. While, you know, living their actual lives.

At the end of the day, Mountain falls in line with dozens of other titles lauded by some for pushing the boundaries of what a game can be and crucified by others for daring to call itself a game at all. I tend to side with the latter, though less harshly, as Mountain did serve as a pretty background time-waster for the few hours I played it. Mountain will definitely appeal to collectors of snow globes and people who like half-heartedly watching ennui-rich land masses against a faint ambient soundtrack. A niche market, for sure, but an â€œexperienceâ€ some may enjoy.

reviewText: This game is an existential crisis simulator. The only real control you have over this mountain is to smash the keys on your keyboard to make noise (or music if you're so inclined - I think you could play most of Claire de Lune if you were skilled enough), which has the effect of making time move faster. You spin faster and seasons come and go in seconds. But what is the point? What meaning does time have to you? You're just an immortal lump of space rock, slowly acquiring meaningless knick-knacks. Time is endless and without purpose to you, so despite being able to control time, you still can't control your life.\n\nThat being said though, this game bored the hell out of me. It's definitely much more than a screensaver, but that doesn't make it any more entertaining than one.  7/10

Mountain is an experimental artistic game. It doesnâ€™t have gameplay, story or even genre. You get to be a mountain, you can play the piano with your keyboard and some songs unlock events and Easter Eggs.

As time passes by, the seasons change, oh and you get hit by objects that get stuck within you. Not sure how many, but I've been hit by a plane, a paper plane, a beach ball, an umbrella, a giant skull and a lot of other random stuff.

It's not going to change the industry, but if most developers started thinking outside the box, like David O'Reilly did here, we could finally play something really new. I mean, no genre, not gameplay, no standard. Only different and new.

reviewText:
Mountain is a neat little time-sink where you watch a chunk of rock slowly turn and grow while constantly making telltale games-style choices, like at what point the best time would be to blow it up.

In all seriousness, I don't get this game. I can appreciate a good art game like Dear Esther and Gone Home but at least there you had some level of agency. In this game you have gimmicks instead, such as raining frogs and raining hearts. I generated a new mountain several times and failed to see much of a difference between them.

It feels more like an artistic statement than an artistic game, and while I don't mind artistic statements I'm not sure I like being charged so that somebody else can make one. If I just wanted to stare at something moving and growing I have a really nice hourglass that I got as a gift (I mean REALLY nice!) and I feel like I'd get just as much enjoyment watching that. In fact I just confirmed it. It moves at more than 20 frames per second, has better sound effects, and if a celestial body comes crashing down it won't look like someone attached a translucent red glass texture to a very low polygon sphere.

So I can't recommend this artistic statement. It has some charm but that alone isn't enough. If you want to see my first impressions of this game, check out my video below. I do indie game first impressions every so often.

reviewText:
A mountain is a large landform that stretches above the surrounding land in a limited area, usually in the form of a peak. A mountain is generally steeper than a hill. Mountains are formed through tectonic forces or volcanism. These forces can locally raise the surface of the earth. Mountains erode slowly through the action of rivers, weather conditions, and glaciers. A few mountains are isolated summits, but most occur in huge mountain ranges.

High elevations on mountains produce colder climates than at sea level. These colder climates strongly affect the ecosystem of mountains: different elevations have different plants and animals. Because of the less hospitable terrain and climate, mountains tend to be used less for agriculture and more for resource extraction and recreation, such as mountain climbing.

The highest mountain on Earth is Mount Everest in the Himalayas of Asia, whose summit is 8,849.868 m (29,035 ft) above mean sea level. The highest known mountain on any planet in the Solar System is Olympus Mons on Mars at 21,171 m (69,459 ft).

reviewText: This is the best game on Steam I have ever encountered.\nIt was given to me as a gift and I can honestly say that I have always wanted to be a mountain. Experiencing the weather, the atmospheric pressure, the random items falling on me and getting stuck in my earthy complexion... it's just all so great. I just adore the structure of the game and the simplicity of it. There's so much you can do yet it's all so easy to get around! I love the feeling when it's raining and the clouds rushing through my grassy top. It just makes you feel so free as you're rotating on your very own axis. The scenery is breathtaking. I just love the random objects that fall and make their home on my mountainside. I feel like we're all a family and we get closer every day. The occasional rainbows are very intriguing and awesome to witness. I love the warm and fuzzy feeling I get in my soil after it rains and the sun comes out, it's just such a unique feeling. The snow brings many challenges but it's also very beautiful. When it's snowing, I have trouble breathing, on account of the snow covering every inch of me. But after... when the sun comes back out and greets me... I just get this rush of an icy-hot sensation as the snow melts. I feel rejuvenated! I feel fresh and clean. Overall, this game is the best I've experienced in my entire 8 years of being on Steam.

reviewText: Although my gametime on this particularly clever game is at a low, I assure you that the hours are soon to be racked up. The beginning of the game made me think of three simple things about life that were more complex than I had ever noticed. The deep thought process along with a blank page gave me an open mind ready to take in something. That something was the meaning of three simple words and then i expressed them with art onto my blank canvas. Afterwards my mountain erupted from seemingly... nothing. It was just there. It was all mine to control, not with controls, but with reason. I felt as if the blank pages that i had spread my deep thoughts on had emerged into something greater. Something self-sufficient. Something that knew where it was headed in the future. Trees began growing. Wind began blowing. Precipitation began falling from the universe around me. At first I was not sure, but now i know.. This mountain is my life, my heart, my soul. It is me taking a journey through the world alone.. just waiting for the next time i experience something greater. Something with more feelings than anything I've ever witnessed.

Mountain is a perfect 12/10. The graphics are amazing. The gameplay is next to none, it's deep and enriching and makes you want to come back for more every day. This, along with the sound design, which is top class, puts you into the world and your are instanly immersed in the lore and background of Mountain.

Your drawings at the begining of the game may seem odd at first but they dramaticaly effect the gameplay as a whole and I was very impressed in seeing that unfold throughout the story I forged. Its less of a game more of an experience.
And story is beautiful paired with the greatest voice acting I've ever seen, or heard, in a game. I expect the voice acting budget was giant and the game lives up the hype. I really enjoyed the hint of a sequel at the end of the game. I hope we can see Mountain II, and jump back into this amazing world. Once again, a perfect 12/10. We may be looking at the next Elder Scrolls. I cant wait to jump into this newfound series for many years to come.

-Michael The Noice Master" Rosen

reviewText:
It is what it is, don't get mad that you didn't do any research before you spent a dollar on something that you had no idea what it was going to be. Personnally I really liked this. It is basically a screen saver, except it feels alive.

I started to feel attached to the mountain I had made, I even found out a way to remove junk from my mountain by throwing it off, or by playing a melody. I was devastated when I played the melody from Close Encounters. My mountain was destroyed by the eye of blindness, it was sad. I ocasionally I leave this running in the background just to see if anything will happen. Its not a game, but its not really anything else other than a game. Just like making Bonsai trees isn't really like being a full-on gardener, but it basically is.

Worth the $1? I don't know, you decide. It's not hard to figure out if you will hate this or appreciate this. I was glad I got it. If it's a game, then it is a really ammusing cheap take on what games are and how we play them (like Little Inferno). If it's a screen saver, then it is a really good interactive screen saver that has way more depth, beauty, and humor than any screensaver I have ever used.

I will give it a thumbs up but you don't have to, and thats okay, just don't buy ignorantly and then complain. It is what it is and you are not forced to buy it. Just ask the mountain what he thinks of himself, he will tell you, and in a very contemplative way too.

reviewText:
I normally don't do reviews for games, nor have I ever attempted to do so, but this game (or so it claims to be) is the first exception in my years of gaming.

The Mountain isn't as much of a game as it is a work of art, it cannot be categorized under any file for the type of game in which it is. The Mountain is a peaceful, thought provoking, philosophical, possible even simulator of what our world is to us and how it is we overcome obstacles, or how we utterly fail and cause our own misfortune and demise.

I may have not owned this game of sorts for many, many hours, but I've already experienced more than I ever would playing a couple hundred ours of any popular game on Steam, and then some. If you're looking for the type of game that provokes you to rethink your view on how the world truly works, I would invite you to come follow in the footsteps of those who bought this game and enjoy it's joyful, yet somewhat melancholy state of euphoria.

It's worth the price, I promise you.
